hints_html:
Steady states are found in this case by solving for the values of x when the derivative is 0.

At points a,b and c to see what happens as time approaches infinity, you need to know whether the derivative is positive (hence the function is increasing) or negative (hence the function is decreasing).
hints_latex:
Steady states are found in this case by solving for the values of
\emph{x} when the derivative is 0.

At points \emph{a},\emph{b} and \emph{c} to see what happens as time
approaches infinity, you need to know whether the derivative is positive
(hence the function is increasing) or negative (hence the function is
decreasing).
hints_raw:
Steady states are found in this case by solving for the values of ''x'' when the derivative is 0.
At points ''a'',''b'' and ''c'' to see what happens as time approaches infinity, you need to know whether the derivative is positive (hence the function is increasing) or negative (hence the function is decreasing).
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
Setting the derivative to 0 and solving gives

\(0 = 4x^{3} - 12x^2 + 8x = 4x(x^2-3x + 2) = 4x(x-1)(x-2)\)

and thus, the steady states are \(x=0,1,2\). At the point a, the derivative is positive and so the function \(x(t)\) is increasing and thus approaches the steady state 1 (the first steady states bigger than a). At b, the dervative is negative hence the function is negative and thus approaches the steady state 1. At c, the derivative is positive and so the function is increasing and as t approaches infinity, the function \(x(t)\) approaches infinity.
sols_latex:
Setting the derivative to 0 and solving gives

$0 = 4x^{3} - 12x^2 + 8x = 4x(x^2-3x + 2) = 4x(x-1)(x-2)$

and thus, the steady states are $x=0,1,2$. At the point a, the
derivative is positive and so the function $x(t)$ is increasing and thus
approaches the steady state 1 (the first steady states bigger than a).
At \emph{b}, the dervative is negative hence the function is negative
and thus approaches the steady state 1. At \emph{c}, the derivative is
positive and so the function is increasing and as \emph{t} approaches
infinity, the function $x(t)$ approaches infinity.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2013/M103W2013Q5b.jpg}
sols_raw:
Setting the derivative to 0 and solving gives

<math>
0 = 4x^{3} - 12x^2 + 8x = 4x(x^2-3x + 2) = 4x(x-1)(x-2)
</math>

and thus, the steady states are <math>x=0,1,2 </math>. At the point a, the derivative is positive and so the function <math> x(t) </math> is increasing and thus approaches the steady state 1 (the first steady states bigger than a). At ''b'', the dervative is negative hence the function is negative and thus approaches the steady state 1. At ''c'', the derivative is positive and so the function is increasing and as ''t'' approaches infinity, the function <math> x(t) </math> approaches infinity.

statement_html: Consider the differential equation \(\displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt} = 4x^{3} - 12x^{2} + 8x\). Calculate the steady states (equilibria) and mark them in the sketch below. Find \(\displaystyle x(t)\) for \(\displaystyle t \to \infty\) for the initial points labeled a,b and c (see sketch).
statement_latex:
Consider the differential equation
$\displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt} = 4x^{3} - 12x^{2} + 8x$. Calculate the
steady states (equilibria) and mark them in the sketch below. Find
$\displaystyle x(t)$ for $\displaystyle t \to \infty$ for the initial
points labeled \emph{a},\emph{b} and \emph{c} (see sketch).

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2013/M103W2013Q5bQ.jpg}
statement_raw:
Consider the differential equation <math> \displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt} = 4x^{3} - 12x^{2} + 8x</math>. Calculate the steady states (equilibria) and mark them in the sketch below. Find <math> \displaystyle  x(t) </math> for <math> \displaystyle  t \to \infty </math> for the initial points labeled ''a'',''b'' and ''c'' (see sketch).
